author: anuragchvn
content:
Built an SSZ verifier with zero dependencies. 118 tests passing across TypeScript, C, and Rust implementations.

Targeting embedded systems and zkVMs. C implementation works with no_std, AFL++ fuzzing found zero crashes after 584K iterations.
code: https://github.com/anuragchvn-blip/ssz-universal-verifier

Looking for feedback on the implementation and testing approaches. Anyone working with SSZ in resource constrained environments?

author: ralexstokes
content: i have been digging a bit into 7688 myself, and echo the concerns above about this being a much bigger lift than it may seem :/

author: ralexstokes
content: my own gut feeling is that this shouldn't go into a fork with even 1 "big" EIP

author: ralexstokes
content: e.g. for glam, testing ePBS is going to be a big lift, and doing 7688 with it just adds more moving targets

author: ralexstokes
content:
some relevant considerations:
* new implementation in production ssz library
  * requires testing, fuzzing, and i think very wise to get an independent audit
* touches consensus types that are also changing in glam
* (curious to hear more if im missing something, but) looks like some validations currently handled in the SSZ layer are pushed to the networking layer (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7688#security-considerations)
  * note: we have relatively less testing capacity around the netowrking specs; there is ongoing work to make them executable so that we can write more direct testing but i think we would be better off doing this first, before adding in a change like this

author: ralexstokes
content:
i'd also suggest removing the https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7688#cleanup-opportunities from this EIP

i'd say if we are serious about doing this well in glam then we should only do the minimum necessary
